turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about TDMoIP.
turn.1: What is the difference between TDM and MoIP?
turn.2: VoIP systems that try to be very bandwidth efficient may also add tens of milliseconds of algorithmic delay in the voice codec.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Historically, bad implementations have added additional, operating-system induced delays, which together with the other delays in practice sometimes approach 100 ms even before taking propagation delays into account.
turn.6: In contrast, TDMoIP maps TDM octets directly into the payload with no voice compression algorithms and no resultant algorithmic delay.
turn.7: Is there any other difference in how they operate?
turn.8: The packetization latency added by TDMoIP depends on the number of cells per packet but is typically in the single millisecond range due to the higher data rate of a complete multiplex as compared to a single VoIP flow.
turn.9: Do they have any other similarities?
turn.10: Playout delay considerations do not differ materially between TDMoIP and VoIP, however, so both work best on paths with controlled packet delay variation (strong overprovisioning or "QoS").
turn.12: Native TDM networks rely on hierarchical distribution of timing.
